author: ajsutton
content: That's possible, but the risk I worry about is if there's a chain split due to a bug in an EE that we wind up with a huge number of validators suddenly being exited at once.  If the client has <50% share the chain would still resolve to the valid fork fine but we could wind up exiting a huge number of validators which then potentially pushes other clients up into supermajority territory which could make things worse.

author: ajsutton
content: I was hoping we could just have a small penalty for each invalid block but actually it would likely have to be reasonably large because a) hitting an chain split is rare and b) only the first block in the fork is likely to be eligible to penalize as the others would have an unknown parent and trying to prove that some earlier block in the chain may get expensive.

author: ajsutton
content: Which probably means I really haven't thought this all through enough to really know what I'm talking about. ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: It feels like exiting the broken clients is the right thing to do here?  That gets us back to finality quickly, and they can rejoin afterwards?

author: ajsutton
content: Exiting them may actually delay finality. If it's like slashing their attestations would be ignored immediately but they'd still be assigned to committees until they get through the exit queue. Whereas if its a client with <50% share they'd just switch back to the valid chain and we likely wouldn't lose finality at all.

author: sky.cactus
content: I guess it depends on whether the bug is in most/every block or few/one block.

author: ajsutton
content: >50% share and the broken clients would go off following their invalid chain and be hit with quadratic leak penalties on the valid chain.  >67% and the invalid chain justifies and then they're stuck over there and will have to exit, get slashed for surround vote or leak out.

author: sky.cactus
content: And whether the bug allows them to still follow the correct chain or permanently splits them off.

author: ajsutton
content: Yeah true - rejecting a valid block incorrectly would mean they'd only come back to the valid chain once they were updated with a fix.

author: ajsutton
content: Accepting an invalid block would be less of a problem.

author: m.kalinin
content:
In principle there is difference between (1) and the rest, (2) and (3) are indistinguishable. I am not sure if there is practical solution to distinguish (1) from the rest -- this is a problem I haven't thought much about, finding a solution to this problem seems at least challenging to me.

Slashing for attesting to invalid block has a trade-off. It allows for punishing adversary but it also opens a way to punish honest validator driven by failing software. IMO, software that follows the protocol should protect from such an attack by rejecting invalid blocks produced and attested by adversary.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think buggy software should be a valid excuse for attacking the network.  We already assert that if buggy software results in signing two competing blocks at the same height then you get slashed.

author: sky.cactus
content: We *should* try to limit the ways in which someone can accidentally get punished as much as possible, but if there is an attack vector I think financial punishment should always be on the table.

content: you can also adjust the size of the punishment depending on how bad the attack is

author: killari.

author: m.kalinin
content: The difference is that signing two competing forks is a step towards finalizing two competing checkpoints, whereas signing off on invalid block is easy to overcome by honest actors

author: sky.cactus
content: IIUC, the attack with signing invalid blocks is that you can get finality of an invalid chain.

author: m.kalinin
content: If this chain is invalid from honest actors' view they won't follow it

author: m.kalinin
content: While if conflicting checkpoint is finalized there is no way to distinguish between honest and malicious chain

author: sky.cactus
content: But if it finalizes, someone doing a checkpoint sync or fastforward may end up  following it.

author: m.kalinin
content: If adversary has enough power to force a node pulling wrong checkpoint there is no need to finalize invalid chain

author: m.kalinin
content: I meant no need for attacker to do this. As other attack vectors are opening in this case, like forcing everyone to start with a conflicting finalized checkpoint

author: m.kalinin
content: IMO, slashing should only be applied for actions that are pushing a system towards a state when fully synced honest node can't decouple honest and malicious chains. Following this logic, having a penalty instead of slashing for not executing a block before attesting to it sounds reasonable. But this worth more thinking of course

author: potuz
content: The problem with this situation is that exactly the opposite is the most likely to happen: in case of a bug in a EE client, we'd see lots of people being slashed and according to your rule they'll end up with a higher penalty.  I agree that it's a subtle issue trying to decide if we slash for behavior that may end up being due to a client bug, but if this behavior is indistinguishable from a coordinated attack, then we need to decide priorities.
